author: Peter Parker

text:
when i think of this song it reminds me of the innocence.  childhood innocence and the what i have lost.

life can be good.  i'm always so confused by people who say life is good all the time, though.  i am over thirty years old and i only have a handful of memories where my life didn't suck.  one of the times where it didn't suck is when my parents were giving me a stable household and a N64 along with this game, playing it, with gameshark, back when pokemon cards came out and obsessing over collecting holographics.  learning at school becoming well-rounded and alternately going outside in the neighborhood to play with fellow neighbor kids, having routines, life making sense then -- going to middle school -- coming home -- going to sleep, then doing it all over again.  Life was good then.  then it stopped being good and i dont' know why.  

I just wish i knew how to get it back or if it's possible.

author: prince apoopoo

text:
Sure, so there is something about Mario 64 that you like better.  I'm just saying that since you prefer 64, it should be better from your perspective too.  

About the nostalgia factor, I guess if nostalgia is truly the main thing that makes you like 64 better, you could claim that you prefer 64 but think Galaxy is a better made game.  But still, from your 1990s perspective, you'd think that 64 is better for you and maybe Galaxy is better for someone who grew up with it in the 2000s.
author: DM584

text: What you've said is reasonable for games that are categorically quite different.  It's possible for you to prefer the games that you play over God of War and still see how others could like it.   But we're comparing two games in the same genre, 64 and Galaxy.  So, if you genuinely prefer 64 over Galaxy, then 64 must have better qualities in your perspective and you should consider it to be a better game.  Others may disagree, but as I said, there's subjectivity even within genres.
author: DM584

text: In your example, you'd be saying that the levels in 64 are better than the levels in Sunshine, not that 64 is overall better.  But what about something like gameplay?  That's more subjective and can't really be quantified since different people look for different things and have inherent biases.  So, unless you can somehow correct for your individual bias, which I think is very hard to do, I don't see how you can prefer one game but still think another is better.
author: DM584

text: Better in what respect?  I agree that there are objective components of any game that might be better than in other games, such as the quality of the graphics, but to say that a game overall is better requires subjectivity.  I could tell you that OOT is better than Superman 64 since it has better graphics, but you could always come back and tell me that you enjoy the gameplay of Superman better.  If you tell me that one game is overall better than another, that can only be your opinion,
author: DM584

text: I also thought that Galaxy was too easy.  In terms of overall levels, it may be longer, but there are no parts of the game that make it especially challenging, whereas Mario 64 did have such parts.  Even the 100 coin and red coin stars, though occasionally monotonous or trivial, were usually fairly difficult but fun.  Also, if you prefer Mario 64, how can say Galaxy is better?  "Better" is just a matter of preference.  Just because one has more levels or variety doesn't make it better.
author: DM584

text: Obviously it's a matter of opinion, but the majority of people who I talk to who played Mario 64 when it came out and then played the Galaxy games liked Mario 64 better.  The game was more challenging, the levels were better designed, and the fact that you could just use a standard controller and not the annoying Wiimote was great.  I really can't see how anyone couldn't like Mario 64 better after playing both.

text: @PaxAmericana24 I can relate a lot to what you're saying. The music fitted perfectly with the ambience of the stage, but didn't really stand out. I wouldn't have been younger than 13 when playing it anyway, so... I was just using this video as a springboard to launch my ideas. I'm deeply grateful for the memories, but find memory alone somehow unfulfilling. I don't want to live my life in retrospect, losing touch with the fire within. I have to tend to the blaze, in whatever form it burns.
author: Harkz0r

text: @Harkz0r Its all true. To be perfectly honest this music didn't phase me so much when I was younger, I found it sleepy and unexciting. It was only after I heard it as I got older that it struck something deeper. As a kid I didn't appreciate the music because I was captive to the 'Magic' of the game. Now, at 21, I am captive to simple memories. Grateful that I experienced the magic when I did though. Heres to hoping our generation builds a better world than whats left to us.
author: PaxAmericana24

text: @PaxAmericana24 Hehe, be careful with that blowing, wouldn't want to break anything! Of course you're right in what you say, and I left two other comments after this one that weren't quite as well received. Basically saying that, as we have those memories in the first place, why can't we cast aside all of this wistful negativity and allow ourselves to experience as wholly as we did while young? It won't be the same, as neither are we, but that doesn't mean it can't still be awesome.
author: Harkz0r

text:
@Harkz0r You're right, yet we can all take some form of solace in sharing each other's memories, fond and foul alike. Obviously this does not bring back the feelings for any of us - but it sure as hell brings back the memories. Damn good ones too.

*blows dust out of cartridge feverishly as if playing a harmonica*

author: torchicguy

text: It's hard in the frenetic pace of responsibilities and adult life to forget about everything, especially if your peers don't feel as you do. You flirt with scorn, misunderstanding and rejection. I even had the foresight to predict this as a child, and it scared me, if only momentarily - which is why I decided to make the most of the time I had then. Life's too short to spend caged by your own negative imaginings. Let it liberate you like it once did before.
author: Harkz0r

text: Even so, that doesn't mean we shouldn't allow ourselves not only to take solace in the memories but also to simply cast aside all the doubts, fears, anxieties and nostalgic wistfulness we carry around with us like so much heavy baggage and just enjoy experiencing things and being alive. How do you think those memories were ever formed in the first place?
author: Harkz0r

text: It is perhaps one of the greatest tragedies of the human condition that we should ever grow up to lose that spark of magic associated with early childhood but it seems to be an inherent biological truth. I think back to games like Parasol Stars and Mario Paint and know for a fact I will never experience the world through the eyes of a 5-year-old again.
